006
007package renderer.models_TP;
008
009import renderer.scene.*;
010import renderer.scene.primitives.*;
011import renderer.scene.util.MeshMaker_TP;
012import renderer.scene.util.MeshType;
013
014/**
015   Create a solid model of a partial torus.
016<p>
017   See <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torus" target="_top">
018                https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torus</a>
019<p>
020   This partial torus is the surface of revolution generated by revolving
021   a sector of the circle in the xy-plane with radius {@code r2} and center
022   {@code (r1,0,0)} part way around the y-axis. We are assuming that
023   {@code r1 > r2}.
024<p>
025   The whole torus is the surface of revolution generated by revolving
026   the whole circle in the xy-plane with radius {@code r2} and center
027   {@code (r1,0,0)} all the way around the y-axis.
028<p>
029   Here are parametric equations for the circle in the xy-plane with
030   radius {@code r2} and center {@code (r1,0,0)} and parameterized
031   starting from the top, with parameter {@code 0 <= phi <= 2*PI}.
032   <pre>{@code
033      x(phi) = r1 + r2 * sin(phi)
034      y(phi) =      r2 * cos(phi)
035      z(phi) = 0
036   }</pre>
037   Here is the 3D rotation matrix that rotates around the y-axis
038   by {@code theta} radians with {@code 0 <= theta <= 2*PI}.
039   <pre>{@code
040      [ cos(theta)   0   sin(theta)]
041      [     0        1       0     ]
042      [-sin(theta)   0   cos(theta)]
043   }</pre>
044   If we multiply the rotation matrix with the circle parameterization,
045   we get a parameterization of the torus.
046   <pre>{@code
047      [ cos(theta)   0   sin(theta)]   [r1 + r2 * sin(phi)]
048      [     0        1       0     ] * [     r2 * cos(phi)]
049      [-sin(theta)   0   cos(theta)]   [        0         ]
050
051      = ( r1*cos(theta) + r2*cos(theta)*sin(phi).
052          r2*cos(phi),
053         -r1*sin(theta) - r2*sin(theta)*sin(phi) )
054
055      = ( (r1 + r2*sin(phi)) * cos(theta),
056                r2*cos(phi),
057         -(r1 + r2*sin(phi)) * sin(theta) )
058   }</pre>
059   See
060     <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torus#Geometry" target="_top">
061              http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torus#Geometry</a>
062
063   @see Torus
064   @see CircleSector
065   @see DiskSector
066   @see RingSector
067   @see ConeSector
068   @see CylinderSector
069   @see SphereSector
070*/
071public class TorusSector extends Model implements MeshMaker_TP
072{
073   public final double r1;
074   public final double r2;
075   public final double theta1;
076   public final double theta2;
077   public final double phi1;
078   public final double phi2;
079   public final int n;
080   public final int k;
081   public final MeshType type;
082
083   /**
084      Create a partial torus with half the circle of revolution with radius 3/4
085      and a cross section that is half the circle of longitude with radius 1/4.
086   */
087   public TorusSector( )
088   {
089      this(0.75, 0.25, Math.PI/2, 3*Math.PI/2, Math.PI, 2*Math.PI, 6, 8);
090   }
091
092
093   /**
094      Create a partial torus with a partial circle of revolution
095      with radius {@code r1} and a cross section circle (circle of
096      longitude) with radius {@code r2}.
097   <p>
098      If {@code theta1 > 0} or {@code theta2 < 2*PI}, then the (partial)
099      circle of revolution is the circular sector from angle {@code theta1}
100      to angle {@code theta2}. In other words, the (partial) circles of
101      latitude in the model extend from angle {@code theta1} to angle
102      {@code theta2}.
103   <p>
104      The last two parameters determine the number of circles of longitude
105      and the number of (partial) circles of latitude in the model.
106   <p>
107      If there are {@code k} circles of longitude, then each (partial)
108      circle of latitude will have {@code k-1} line segments.
109      If there are {@code n} (partial) circles of latitude, then each
110      circle of longitude will have {@code n} line segments.
111   <p>
112      There must be at least four circles of longitude and at least
113      three circles of latitude.
114
115      @param r1      radius of the circle of revolution
116      @param r2      radius of the cross section circle (circle of longitude)
117      @param theta1  beginning longitude angle for the circle of revolution (in radians)
118      @param theta2  ending longitude angle for the circle of revolution (in radians)
119      @param n       number of circles of latitude
120      @param k       number of circles of longitude
121      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code n} is less than 4
122      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code k} is less than 4
123   */
124   public TorusSector(final double r1, final double r2,
125                      final double theta1, final double theta2,
126                      final int n, final int k)
127   {
128      this(r1, r2, theta1, theta2, 0, 2*Math.PI, n+1, k);
129   }
130
131
132   /**
133      Create a partial torus with a partial circle of revolution with
134      radius {@code r1} and a partial cross section circle with radius
135      {@code r2}.
136   <p>
137      If {@code phi1 > 0} or {@code phi2 < 2*PI}, then the (partial) cross
138      section circle is the circular sector from angle {@code phi1} to angle
139      {@code phi2}. In other words, the (partial) circles of longitude in the
140      model extend from angle {@code phi1} to angle {@code phi2}.
141   <p>
142      If {@code theta1 > 0} or {@code theta2 < 2*PI}, then the (partial) circle
143      of revolution is the circular sector from angle {@code theta1} to angle
144      {@code theta2}. In other words, the (partial) circles of latitude in
145      the model extend from angle {@code theta1} to angle {@code theta2}.
146   <p>
147      The last two parameters determine the number of (partial) circles of
148      longitude and the number of (partial) circles of latitude in the model.
149   <p>
150      If there are {@code k} circles of longitude, then each (partial)
151      circle of latitude will have {@code k-1} line segments.
152      If there are {@code n} (partial) circles of latitude, then each
153      circle of longitude will have {@code n-1} line segments.
154   <p>
155      There must be at least four circles of longitude and at least
156      four circles of latitude.
157
158      @param r1      radius of the circle of revolution
159      @param r2      radius of the cross section circle (circle of longitude)
160      @param theta1  beginning longitude angle for the circle of revolution (in radians)
161      @param theta2  ending longitude angle for the circle of revolution (in radians)
162      @param phi1    beginning latitude angle for the cross section circle
163      @param phi2    ending latitude angle for the cross section circle
164      @param n       number of circles of latitude
165      @param k       number of circles of longitude
166      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code n} is less than 4
167      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code k} is less than 4
168   */
169   public TorusSector(final double r1,     final double r2,
170                      final double theta1, final double theta2,
171                      final double phi1,   final double phi2,
172                      final int n, final int k)
173   {
174      this(r1, r2, theta1, theta2, phi1, phi2, n, k, MeshType.HORIZONTAL);
175   }
176
177
178   /**
179      Create a partial torus with a partial circle of revolution
180      with radius {@code r1} and a cross section circle (circle of
181      longitude) with radius {@code r2}.
182   <p>
183      If {@code theta1 > 0} or {@code theta2 < 2*PI}, then the (partial)
184      circle of revolution is the circular sector from angle {@code theta1}
185      to angle {@code theta2}. In other words, the (partial) circles of
186      latitude in the model extend from angle {@code theta1} to angle
187      {@code theta2}.
188   <p>
189      The last two parameters determine the number of circles of longitude
190      and the number of (partial) circles of latitude in the model.
191   <p>
192      If there are {@code k} circles of longitude, then each (partial)
193      circle of latitude will have {@code k-1} line segments.
194      If there are {@code n} (partial) circles of latitude, then each
195      circle of longitude will have {@code n} line segments.
196   <p>
197      There must be at least four circles of longitude and at least
198      three circles of latitude.
199
200      @param r1      radius of the circle of revolution
201      @param r2      radius of the cross section circle (circle of longitude)
202      @param theta1  beginning longitude angle for the circle of revolution (in radians)
203      @param theta2  ending longitude angle for the circle of revolution (in radians)
204      @param n       number of circles of latitude
205      @param k       number of circles of longitude
206      @param type  choose between striped and checkerboard triangle strips
207      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code n} is less than 4
208      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code k} is less than 4
209   */
210   public TorusSector(final double r1, final double r2,
211                      final double theta1, final double theta2,
212                      final int n, final int k,
213                      final MeshType type)
214   {
215      this(r1, r2, theta1, theta2, 0, 2*Math.PI, n+1, k, type);
216   }
217
218
219   /**
220      Create a partial torus with a partial circle of revolution with
221      radius {@code r1} and a partial cross section circle with radius
222      {@code r2}.
223   <p>
224      If {@code phi1 > 0} or {@code phi2 < 2*PI}, then the (partial) cross
225      section circle is the circular sector from angle {@code phi1} to angle
226      {@code phi2}. In other words, the (partial) circles of longitude in the
227      model extend from angle {@code phi1} to angle {@code phi2}.
228   <p>
229      If {@code theta1 > 0} or {@code theta2 < 2*PI}, then the (partial) circle
230      of revolution is the circular sector from angle {@code theta1} to angle
231      {@code theta2}. In other words, the (partial) circles of latitude in
232      the model extend from angle {@code theta1} to angle {@code theta2}.
233   <p>
234      The last two parameters determine the number of (partial) circles of
235      longitude and the number of (partial) circles of latitude in the model.
236   <p>
237      If there are {@code k} circles of longitude, then each (partial)
238      circle of latitude will have {@code k-1} line segments.
239      If there are {@code n} (partial) circles of latitude, then each
240      circle of longitude will have {@code n-1} line segments.
241   <p>
242      There must be at least four circles of longitude and at least
243      four circles of latitude.
244
245      @param r1      radius of the circle of revolution
246      @param r2      radius of the cross section circle (circle of longitude)
247      @param theta1  beginning longitude angle for the circle of revolution (in radians)
248      @param theta2  ending longitude angle for the circle of revolution (in radians)
249      @param phi1    beginning latitude angle for the cross section circle (in radians)
250      @param phi2    ending latitude angle for the cross section circle (in radians)
251      @param n       number of circles of latitude
252      @param k       number of circles of longitude
253      @param type  choose between striped and checkerboard triangle strips
254      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code n} is less than 4
255      @throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code k} is less than 4
256   */
257   public TorusSector(final double r1,     final double r2,
258                      final double theta1, final double theta2,
259                      final double phi1,   final double phi2,
260                      final int n, final int k,
261                      final MeshType type)
262   {
263      super(String.format("Torus Sector(%.2f,%.2f,%.2f,%.2f,%.2f,%.2f,%d,%d)",
264                           r1, r2, theta1, theta2, phi1, phi2, n, k));
265
266      if (n < 4)
267         throw new IllegalArgumentException("n must be greater than 3");
268      if (k < 4)
269         throw new IllegalArgumentException("k must be greater than 3");
270
271      this.r1 = r1;
272      this.r2 = r2;
273      this.theta1 = theta1;
274      this.theta2 = theta2;
275      this.phi1 = phi1;
276      this.phi2 = phi2;
277      this.n = n;
278      this.k = k;
279      this.type = type;
280
281      // Create the torus's geometry.
282
283      final double deltaPhi = (phi2 - phi1) / (n - 1),
284                   deltaTheta = (theta2 - theta1) / (k - 1);
285
286      // An array of vertices to be used to create triangles.
287      final Vertex[][] v = new Vertex[n][k];
288
289      // Create all the vertices.
290      for (int j = 0; j < k; ++j) // choose a rotation around the y-axis
291      {
292         final double c1 = Math.cos(theta1 + j * deltaTheta),
293                      s1 = Math.sin(theta1 + j * deltaTheta);
294         for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i)  // go around a cross section circle
295         {
296            final double c2 = Math.cos(phi1 + i * deltaPhi),
297                         s2 = Math.sin(phi1 + i * deltaPhi);
298            v[i][j] = new Vertex( (r1 + r2*s2) * c1,
299                                        r2*c2,
300                                 -(r1 + r2*s2) * s1 );
301         }
302      }
303
304      // Add all of the vertices to this model.
305      for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i)
306      {
307         for (int j = 0; j < k; ++j)
308         {
309            addVertex( v[i][j] );
310         }
311      }
312
313      // Create all the triangle strips.
314      if (MeshType.HORIZONTAL == type)
315      {
316         for (int i = 0; i < n - 1; ++i)
317         {
318            final Primitive triStrip = new TriangleStrip();
319            for (int j = 0; j < k; ++j)
320            {
321               triStrip.addIndex(   i * k + j);  // v[i  ][j]
322               triStrip.addIndex((1+i)* k + j);  // v[i+1][j]
323            }
324            addPrimitive(triStrip);
325         }
326      }
327      else if (MeshType.VERTICAL == type)
328      {
329         for (int j = 0; j < k - 1; ++j)
330         {
331            final Primitive triStrip = new TriangleStrip();
332            for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i)
333            {
334               triStrip.addIndex(i * k + j+1);  // v[i][j+1]
335               triStrip.addIndex(i * k + j);    // v[i][j  ]
336            }
337            addPrimitive(triStrip);
338         }
339         final Primitive triStrip = new TriangleStrip();
340      }
341      else // MeshType.CHECKER triangle strips
342      {
343         for (int i = 0; i < n - 1; ++i)
344         {
345            for (int j = 0; j < k - 1; ++j)
346            {
347               addPrimitive(
348                  new TriangleStrip(   i * k + j,       // v[i  ][j  ]
349                                    (1+i)* k + j,       // v[i+1][j  ]
350                                       i * k + j + 1,   // v[i  ][j+1]
351                                    (1+i)* k + j + 1)); // v[i+1][j+1]
352            }
353         }
354      }
355   }
356
357
358
359   // Implement the MeshMaker_TP interface (four methods).
360   @Override public int getHorzCount() {return n;}
361
362   @Override public int getVertCount() {return k;}
363
364   @Override public MeshType getType() {return type;}
365
366   @Override
367   public TorusSector remake(final int n, final int k, final MeshType type)
368   {
369      return new TorusSector(this.r1,     this.r2,
370                             this.theta1, this.theta2,
371                             this.phi1,   this.phi2,
372                             n, k,
373                             type);
374   }
375}//TorusSector
